text:
SANDRA CHA: I'm still telling
people about flash talks

that I saw a few years ago
and was very moved by so I'm
honored to be here.

Before starting, I'd like to
thank my wonderful co-author
Laura Morgan Roberts.

From the Hilton
Hospitality Group

to Google to the
Ford Motor Company,

more and more companies
are embracing the idea

that having a
diverse workforce is

crucial for their bottom line,
also known as the business
case for diversity.

Cultural minorities,
from lower status groups

such as women and
racial minorities,

are believed to bring
diverse perspectives

to the organizations
as well as insight
into minority consumers.

Through our research, which
is forthcoming in Organization

Science, we came to see that
the ability of a company

to capitalize on the promised
benefits of diversity

is ultimately in the hands
of minority employees.

It is their choice
to draw or not

to draw on their
identity-based strengths.

We conducted a qualitative
study of 47 racial minority

journalists asking how
individuals perceive and act

upon any advantages associated
with their minority identity.

And what emerged was a
story of resourcefulness.

The journalists described
four different ways

in which they drew upon identity
resources, potentially valuable

features associated with
the minority identity

to help themselves progress
toward work-related goals.

For example, one
African-American journalist

described writing articles
about African-Americans

in public housing in which he
challenged common assumptions.

It would have been easy for
him to fall back on stereotypes

of people drinking,
gambling, and, quote,

"the mom with the kid on
her hip and a cigarette

hanging out of her
mouth," he said.

But instead, he took the risk of
writing unconventional stories

about people looking
to do better,

people who needed a, quote,
"hand up instead of a hand

out," success stories,
kids, and the problems
within public housing.

In doing, so he provided
a richer and more complete

description of the truth
about public housing.

But mobilizing identity, rather
than being only beneficial,

was associated with tensions or
sources of stress and strain.

For example, those who
challenge stereotypes

face the risk of being
perceived or branded

as a disruptive
minority or an activist.

One Asian-American
journalist faced this tension

in challenging the assumption
that Asian-Americans
know everything about Asia.

Her editors were blindly
assigning her to do
every story related to Asia.

She did them at first, but
then she said to her editor,

think about why you're
asking me to do this.

Is it because I have
special expertise
in US-Taiwan relations?
I don't think so.

The story had nothing to do with
her coverage area, her language

skills, or her South
Asian heritage.

And she didn't feel qualified
or motivated to do this story.

Upon being
challenged, her editor

looked very uncomfortable
and finally said,
you don't have to do the story.

In sum, identity
mobilization was not just
a story of resourcefulness.

It was also a story
of agency and courage,

the courage to recognize
and draw upon differences,

to mobilize in the
face of tensions,

and to enact agency
by not mobilizing

in the face of ill suited
pressure from others.

Moving forward, while our study
focused on racial identity,

the journalists also described
mobilizing or not mobilizing
other minority identities.

One described wanting to
mobilize her female identity

to write stories about
gender but decided not to

because she felt her
male editor didn't value

and would be threatened
by stories about women.

Another journalist mobilized
her multiple identities

as an African-American
woman and mother

to build trust with a source,
an African-American mother whose

child was killed
in a hate crime.

We hope that other
scholars will join us,

perhaps mobilizing
their own identities,

as we keep exploring what it
means to leverage minority
identities at work.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
